Award.AwardTitle: Increasing the Efficiency of Wind Turbines through Understanding of Their Transient Responses

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Global demand for renewable energy is increasing, and wind power is the fastest growing source of renewable energy. Current control methods for wind turbines are designed for steady-state wind and are unable to capture the extra energy from turbulence. To capture more energy from unsteady wind, the complex flow over a pitching blade needs to be understood. This award supports fundamental research to understand wind turbine response to time-varying wind and blade pitch facilitating the creation of new control laws for wind turbines.

The research objective of this project is to understand the transient response of wind turbines to control law and time varying wind and blade pitch. In turbulent flow, the wind turbine response and the control law are inter-connected and must be treated as a complete nonlinear, time-varying system. For this reason, understanding how the control law affects the overall system response is included in the research objective. To achieve the research objective, load cell measurements of lift force, drag force, and moment of wind turbine blades under unsteady wind and blade pitch conditions will be collected at the large closed return wind tunnel facility at the University of Minnesota. A fan driven by a variable frequency drive producing a maximum wind velocity of 38 m/s controls the wind speed. The pitch blade angle will be controlled by an electric motor in the range of -2 to +4 degrees. The frequency content of the time-varying wind and blade pitch motion inputs will cover the range of interest in the wind spectrum. Control laws to be investigated include torque-based control and state-based control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

This research aims to develop an efficient and reliable hydrostatic drive train (HST) for community wind turbines by implementing an advanced controller to maximize energy capture in unsteady wind with pitching blade.

A conventional turbine is equipped with a heavy, bulky, fixed-ratio gearbox. An HST is a continuously variable transmission (CVT) that is simpler, lighter, more reliable, more cost effective, and offers higher power density than a fixed-ratio gearbox.  It decouples the generator speed from the rotor speed and allows the generator to rotate at a constant speed despite time varying wind. The HST eliminates the need for an expensive power converter and bulky gearbox. As a demonstration testbed, a 100 kW HST drive train for community wind turbines with a fixed displacement pump and a variable displacement motor HST is considered in this research.

To validate the performance of the HST, a novel power regenerative test platform was successfully designed, constructed and commissioned. It has two hydrostatic closed loops, coupled to each other. The research platform is capable of generating 100 kW (output) with only 55 kW of electrical power as an input by taking advantage of power regeneration. The test platform is a multi-domain system, consisting of electrical, mechanical and hydraulic components. A decentralized controller was designed to control the rotor speed and pressure of the system. The startup and shut down algorithms developed, enabled smooth operation of the test bed without a cavitation and pressure spikes.

The performance of the HST was validated under various wind profile inputs. A pressure control strategy was developed to maximize the power capture. A hardware-in-the-loop simulation was implemented to mimic the wind turbine environment. The turbine rotor dynamics are emulated on the test platform through a decoupling controller. We examined the results of the HST drive train in transient and steady conditions. The efficiency of the HST wind turbine estimated from these experiments was comparable with that of a conventional turbine.

Finally, the feasibility of connecting an HST wind turbine to the grid via a synchronous generator was studied. We found that the generator terminal voltage and frequency comply with the grid regulation band under all operating conditions. This strategy circumvents the need of expensive power electronics.

This research offers novel insights of the HST for wind turbine applications. The outcomes of the project will stimulate industry to develop more efficient hydraulic components, systems and controls for wind applications and contribute to a greener economy.

Broader Impact:

As a clean and renewable energy source, wind power has drawn increasing interest not only from scientists and engineers, but also from society generally. Society will benefit from the development of more efficient, reliable and cost-effective components, systems and controls for wind turbines. This will lead to the expansion of the green economy by enabling the practical use of improved technology in renewable energy. Accelerating the development of renewable energy technology will reduce our dependence on fossil fuels and reduce the emission of greenhouse gasses, making a profound impact on the environment and the wind industry.

There is a strong need for talented engineers to shape the future of the wind industry. Motivated by this, the goal of the education and outreach program of this project is to attract young talented engineers, especially women and underrepresented minorities, into this field, and to educate them to be future technical innovators in wind energy. The educational program of this project will inspire the next generation of researchers and engineers to lead technical innovations for future wind energy systems. It provided a good opportunity for the REU (Research Experience for Undergraduate) students on this project to have a rich research experience in the renewable energy systems and fluid power fields. The project provided an opportunity for three graduate students, seven REU students and five international visitors.
